unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Which Type of Significance Test to Use: Sporting Event
question_text:
In a random sample of $100$ consumers at a sports store, $64$ indicated that they had gone to a professional sporting event in the past year. In an independent random sample of $75$ consumers from a bookstore, $15$ said they had gone to a professional sporting event in the past year.
What significance test should be used to determine whether the proportion of consumers at a sports store attending a sporting event in the past year is significantly greater than the proportion of consumers at a bookstore attending a sporting event in the past year?
solution:
First, this problem is asking to compare proportions. This makes Choice 'B' the correct answer.

Explanation of Distractors

We can eliminate Choices 'D and 'E' since it asking about proportions and not mean, as stated in both choices.

We have two independent random samples making this a two sample test. We can eliminate Choice 'A' as it is two samples and not one sample.

Choice 'C' is incorrect as a chi-square goodness-of-fit is used to test whether the distribution of a categorical variable differs from some specified distribution. In our case we have two categorical variables the type of store and if they attended a sporting event. Also we are not looking to compare to a specified distribution.

A chi-square goodness-of-fit would be rolling a six-sided die 100 times and recording the proportion of each number you received and comparing it to the theoretical proportions for those outcomes.
